an10.46:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
an10.46:1.2: Then on the sabbath several Sakyan lay followers went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:
an10.46:1.3: “Sakyans, do you observe the sabbath with its eight factors?”
an10.46:1.4: “Sir, sometimes we do, sometimes we don’t.”
an10.46:1.5: “That’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.
an10.46:2.2: Take a man who earns half a dollar for an honest day’s work.
an10.46:2.3: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”
an10.46:3.2: Take a man who earns a dollar for an honest day’s work.
an10.46:3.3: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”
an10.46:4.2: Take a man who, for an honest day’s work, earns two dollars …
an10.46:4.16: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”
an10.46:5.2: Suppose that man earned a hundred or a thousand dollars every day and saved it all up. If he lived for a hundred years, would he not accumulate a large mass of wealth?”
an10.46:6.2: Would that man, on account of that wealth, experience perfect happiness for a single day or night, or even half a day or night?”
an10.46:6.5: “Because sensual pleasures, sir, are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive.”
an10.46:7.1: “But take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for ten years, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years.
an10.46:7.2: And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or guaranteed a stream-enterer.
an10.46:8.1: take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for nine years …
an10.46:12.9: Let alone two days, take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for one day, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years. And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or guaranteed a stream-enterer.
an10.46:12.10: It’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.”
an10.46:12.11: “Well, sir, from this day forth we will observe the sabbath with its eight factors.”
